text: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
label: BODY

text: FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF WEST VIRGINIA
label: BODY

text: SHAWN G. HARRIS,
label: BODY

text: Petitioner,
label: BODY

text: Civil Action No. 5:06CV141
label: BODY

text: Criminal Action No. 5:05CR41-01
label: BODY

text: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA,
label: BODY

text: (JUDGE STAMP)
label: BODY

text: Respondent.
label: BODY

text: REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION
label: HH1

text: THAT §2255 MOTION BE DENIED AS TO THREE GROUNDS, SETTING AN
label: HH2

text: EVIDENTIARY HEARING ON GROUND ONE, APPOINTING COUNSEL FOR THE
label: HH2

text: EVIDENTIARY HEARING AND PROVIDING THAT COUNSEL, PARTIES AND
label: HH2

text: WITNESSES MORE THAN 40 MILES FROM THE WHEELING POINT OF HOLDING
label: HH2

text: COURT MAY APPEAR BY VIDEO OR TELEPHONE CONFERENCING
label: HH3

text: I. INTRODUCTION
label: HH2

text: On November 20, 2006, pro se petitioner filed a Motion Under 28 U.S.C. § 2255 to
label: BODY

text: Vacate, Set Aside or Correct Sentence by a Person in Federal Custody. The Government filed its
label: BODY

text: Response January 26, 2007. Petitioner filed a Response to the Government’s Response February
label: BODY

text: II. FACTS
label: HH1

text: Conviction and Sentence
label: HH3

text: On October 14, 2005, petitioner signed a plea agreement by which he agreed to plead
label: BODY

text: guilty to Count One, conspiracy to distribute more than five (5) grams of cocaine base, in
label: BODY

text: violation of Title 21, United States Code, Sections 846 and 841(b)(1)(B). In the plea agreement,
label: BODY

text: the parties stipulated to the total drug relevant conduct of between thirty-five (35) and fifty (50)
label: BODY

text: grams of cocaine base. Additionally, the petitioner waived his right to appeal and to collaterally
label: BODY

text: attack his sentence. Specifically, the petitioner’s plea agreement contained the following
label: BODY

text: language regarding his waiver:
label: BODY

text: Mr. Harris is aware that Title 18, United States Code,
label: BODY

text: Section 3742 affords a defendant the right to appeal the sentence
label: BODY

text: imposed. Acknowledging all this, and in exchange for the
label: BODY

text: concessions made by the United States in this plea agreement, if
label: BODY

text: the Court sentences defendant to 97 months or less, defendant
label: BODY

text: knowingly and voluntarily waives the right to appeal his sentence
label: BODY

text: or in the manner in which that sentence was determined on any
label: BODY

text: ground whatever, including those grounds set forth in Title 18,
label: BODY

text: United States Code, Section 3742. The defendant also waives his
label: BODY

text: right to challenge his sentence or the manner in which it was
label: BODY

text: determined in any collateral attack, including but not limited to, a
label: BODY

text: motion brought under Title 28, United States Code, Section 2255
label: BODY

text: (habeas corpus).  Correspondingly, the United States waives its
label: BODY

text: right to appeal if the Court sentences the defendant to 78 months or
label: BODY

text: more. Neither of these ranges are representative of defendant’s
label: BODY

text: estimation of a reasonable sentence, nor does this waiver prevent
label: BODY

text: defendant from arguing for a sentence below 78 months.
label: BODY

text: On October 16, 2005, the petitioner entered his plea in open court. Petitioner was 31 years
label: BODY

text: old and a high school graduate. (Plea transcript p. 4) Petitioner stated he understood and agreed
label: BODY

text: with all the terms and conditions of the plea agreement. (Id. at 11) The Court specifically asked
label: BODY

text: if petitioner understood the waiver of appellate and post-conviction relief rights. (Id. at 12-13;
label: BODY

text: 16-17) The Court asked petitioner’s counsel if he believed petitioner understood the waiver of
label: BODY

text: appellate and post-conviction relief rights. (Id. at 12) The Court then reviewed all the rights
label: BODY

text: petitioner was giving up by pleading guilty. (Id. at 17-20) During the plea hearing, the
label: BODY

text: Government presented the testimony of Special Agent Robert Manchas of the United States
label: BODY

text: Drug Enforcement Administration to establish a factual basis for the plea. (Id. at  20-22). The
label: BODY

text: petitioner did not contest the factual basis of the plea.
label: BODY

text: After the Government presented the factual basis of the plea, the petitioner advised the
label: BODY

text: Court that he was guilty of Count One of the indictment. (Id. at 23) The petitioner further stated
label: BODY

text: under oath that no one had attempted to force him to plead guilty. (Id.) In addition, he testified
label: BODY

text: that the plea was not the result of any promises other than those contained in the plea agreement.
label: BODY

text: (Id.) The petitioner testified that his attorney had adequately represented him, and that his
label: BODY

text: attorney had left nothing undone. (Id. at 24) Finally, petitioner said he was in fact guilty of the
label: BODY

text: crime to which he was pleading guilty (Id.)
label: BODY

text: At the conclusion of the hearing, the Court determined that the plea was made freely and
label: BODY

text: voluntarily, that the petitioner understood the consequences of pleading guilty; and that the
label: BODY

text: elements of Count One were established beyond a reasonable doubt. (Id. at 24-25)  The
label: BODY

text: petitioner did not object to the Court’s finding.
label: BODY

text: On December 12, 2005 and December 16, 2005, the petitioner appeared before the Court
label: BODY

text: for sentencing. After considering several factors, including the circumstances of both the crime
label: BODY

text: and the defendant, and the sentencing objectives of punishment, the Court sentenced the
label: BODY

text: petitioner to a term of 57 months imprisonment.
label: BODY

text: Appeal
label: HH3

text: Petitioner did not file an appeal of his conviction or sentence.
label: BODY

text: Federal Habeas Corpus
label: HH3

text: On November 20, 2006, petitioner initiated this case under § 2255. In the motion, the
label: BODY

text: petitioner asserts that his counsel was ineffective for failing to file a notice of appeal upon his
label: BODY

text: request. He further contends that his counsel was ineffective for not obtaining further sentence
label: BODY

text: reductions per Rule 35 for petitioner’s substantial assistance to the Government. Petitioner
label: BODY

text: contends that his sentence should be reduced under a potential new law, which addresses the
label: BODY

text: difference in crack cocaine and powder cocaine under the Sentencing Guidelines. Lastly,
label: BODY

text: petitioner requests an evidentiary hearing on these matters.
label: BODY

text: In its response to the motion, the Government asserts that under Fourth Circuit law,
label: BODY

text: counsel’s failure to file a notice of appeal when requested to do so is per se ineffective assistance
label: BODY

text: and that an evidentiary hearing is appropriate for this issue. However, the government contends
label: BODY

text: that petitioner’s counsel was not ineffective for not moving for the Rule 35 motion, as defense
label: BODY

text: counsel has no legal authority to so. The Government further clarifies that petitioner did not
label: BODY

text: work as a confidential informant to receive substantial assistance, but received a sentence
label: BODY

text: reduction under the safety vale and for acceptance of responsibility. Finally, the Government
label: BODY

text: contends that petitioner’s request for relief based on anticipated Congressional action is
label: BODY

text: premature and moot.
label: BODY

text: Recommendation
label: HH3

text: Based upon a review of the record, the undersigned recommends that the petitioner’s §
label: BODY

text: 2255 motion be denied and dismissed from the docket because petitioner knowingly,
label: BODY

text: intelligently, and voluntarily waived the right to collaterally attack the sentence with the
label: BODY

text: exception of an evidentiary hearing to determine whether petitioner requested his attorney to file
label: BODY

text: an appeal and whether counsel ignored or refused instructions.
label: BODY

text: III. ANALYSIS
label: HH1

text: Waiver
label: HH3

text: “[T]he guilty plea and the often concomitant plea bargain are important components of
label: BODY

text: this country’s criminal justice system. Properly administered, they can benefit all concerned.”
label: BODY

text: Blackledge v. Allison, 431 U.S. 63, 71 (1977). However, the advantages of plea bargains “can be
label: BODY

text: secure . . . only if dispositions by guilty plea are accorded a great measure of finality.” Id. “To
label: BODY

text: this end, the Government often secures waivers of appellate rights from criminal defendants as
label: BODY

text: part of their plea agreement.” United States v. Lemaster, 403 F.3d 216, 220 (4th Cir. 2005).
label: BODY

text: In United States v. Attar, 38 F.3d 727 (4th Cir. 1994), the Fourth Circuit found that “a
label: BODY

text: waiver-of-appeal-rights provision in a valid plea agreement is enforceable against the defendant
label: BODY

text: so long as it is the result of a knowing and intelligent decision to forgo the right to appeal.” Attar
label: BODY

text: at 731. The Fourth Circuit then found that whether a waiver is knowing and intelligent “depends
label: BODY

text: upon the particular facts and circumstances surrounding [its making], including the background,
label: BODY

text: experience, and conduct of the accused.” Id. After upholding the general validity of a waiver-of-
label: BODY

text: appeal-rights provision, the Fourth Circuit noted that even with a waiver-of-appeals-rights
label: BODY

text: provision, a defendant may obtain appellate review of certain limited grounds. Id. at 732. For
label: BODY

text: example, the Court noted that a defendant “could not be said to have waived his right to appellate
label: BODY

text: review of a sentence imposed in excess of the maximum penalty provided by statute or based on
label: BODY

text: a constitutionally impermissible factor such as race.” Id. Nor did the Court believe that a
label: BODY

text: defendant “can fairly be said to have waived his right to appeal his sentence on the ground that
label: BODY

text: the proceedings following the entry of the guilty plea were conducted in violation of the Sixth
label: BODY

text: Amendment right to counsel.” Id.
label: BODY

text: Subsequently, in United States v. Lemaster, supra, the Fourth Circuit saw no reason to
label: BODY

text: distinguish between waivers of direct appeal rights and waivers of collateral attack rights.
label: BODY

text: Lemaster, 403 F.3d at 220. Therefore, like waiver-of-appeal-rights provision, the Court found
label: BODY

text: that the waiver of the right to collaterally attack a sentence is valid as long as it is knowing and
label: BODY

text: voluntary. Id. And, although, the Court expressly declined to address whether the same
label: BODY

text: exceptions apply since Lemaster failed to make such an argument, the court stressed that it “saw
label: BODY

text: no reason to distinguish between waivers of direct-appeal rights and waivers of collateral-attack
label: BODY

text: rights.” Id. at n. 2.
label: BODY

text: Based on these cases, it appears that ineffective assistance of counsel claims are barred
label: BODY

text: by a valid waiver, to the extent that the facts giving rise to the claims occurred prior to the
label: BODY

text: defendant entering his guilty plea. Only claims arising after the entry of the guilty plea may fall
label: BODY

text: outside the scope of the waiver. Lemaster, 403 F.3d at 732 (it cannot be fairly said that a
label: BODY

text: defendant “waived his right to appeal his sentence on the ground that the proceedings following
label: BODY

text: entry of the guilty plea were conducted in violation of the Sixth Amendment right to counsel, for
label: BODY

text: a defendant’s agreement to waive appellate review of his sentence is implicitly conditioned on
label: BODY

text: the assumption that the proceedings following entry of the plea will be conducted in accordance
label: BODY

text: with constitutional limitations.”)
label: BODY

text: Therefore, when reviewing an ineffective assistance of counsel claim in a case where
label: BODY

text: there is a waiver of collateral-attack rights in a plea agreement, we must first determine whether
label: BODY

text: there is valid waiver. In doing so,
label: BODY

text: The validity of an appeal waiver depends on whether the defendant
label: BODY

text: knowingly and intelligently agreed to waive the right to appeal.
label: BODY

text: Although this determination is often made based on adequacy of
label: BODY

text: the plea colloquy -- specifically, whether the district court
label: BODY

text: questioned the defendant about the appeal waiver – the issue
label: BODY

text: ultimately is evaluated by reference to the totality of the
label: BODY

text: circumstances. Thus, the determination must depend, in each case,
label: BODY

text: upon the particular facts and circumstances surrounding that case,
label: BODY

text: including the background, experience, and conduct of the accused.
label: BODY

text: United States v. Blick, 408 F.3d 162, 169 (4th Cir. 2005) (internal citations and quotations
label: BODY

text: omitted).
label: BODY

text: In other words, the Court must examine the actual waiver provision, the plea agreement as a
label: BODY

text: whole, the plea colloquy, and the defendant’s ability to understand the proceedings. Id. If the
label: BODY

text: Court finds that the waiver is valid, any IAC claims arising prior to the plea agreement are barred
label: BODY

text: by the waiver.
label: BODY

text: As to any IAC claims made regarding an attorney’s action, or lack thereof, after the plea
label: BODY

text: agreement, the Fourth Circuit has stated, “[w]e do not think the general waiver of the right to
label: BODY

text: challenge” a sentence on the ground  that “the proceedings following entry of the guilty plea –
label: BODY

text: including both the sentencing hearing itself and the presentation of the motion to withdraw their
label: BODY

text: pleas – were conducted in violation of their Sixth Amendment right to counsel.” Lemaster, 403
label: BODY

text: F.3d at 732-33. Therefore, upon first blush it appears that IAC claims arising after the guilty plea
label: BODY

text: and/or during sentencing, are not barred by a general waiver-of appeal rights.
label: BODY

text: However, several courts have distinguished IAC claims raised in a § 2255 case, from
label: BODY

text: those raised on direct appeal. In Braxton v. United States, 358 F.Supp.2d 497 (W.D Va. 2005),
label: BODY

text: the Western District of Virginia noted that although the Fourth Circuit has yet to define the scope
label: BODY

text: of waiver of collateral rights, several courts have held that § 2255 waivers should be subject to
label: BODY

text: the same conditions and exceptions applicable to waivers of the right to file a direct appeal.
label: BODY

text: Braxton at 502 (citing United States v. Cannady, 283 F.3d 641,645 n. 3 (4th Cir. 2000)
label: BODY

text: (collecting cases); Butler v. United States, 173 F.Supp.2d 489, 493 (E.D. Va. 2001)).
label: BODY

text: Nonetheless, the Western District of Virginia, distinguished the types of IAC claims available on
label: BODY

text: direct appeal from those available in a § 2255 motion. Specifically, the Court noted:
label: BODY

text: Appellate courts rarely hear ineffective assistance of
label: BODY

text: counsel claims on direct review. Indeed, ‘[i]t is well settled that a
label: BODY

text: claim of ineffective assistance should be raised in a 28 U.S.C. §
label: BODY

text: 2255 motion in the district court rather than on direct appeal,
label: BODY

text: unless the record conclusively shows ineffective assistance.’
label: BODY

text: United States v. King, 119 F.3d 290, 295 (4th Cir. 1997).
label: BODY

text: Therefore, the waiver exception recognized in Attar applies only to
label: BODY

text: a very narrow category of cases. In contrast, a rule that defendants
label: BODY

text: are unable to waive their right to bring an ineffective  assistance
label: BODY

text: claim in a § 2255 would create a large exception to the scope of §
label: BODY

text: 2255 waivers. In fact, such an exception would render all such
label: BODY

text: waivers virtually meaningless because most habeas challenges can
label: BODY

text: be pressed into the mold of a Sixth Amendment claim on collateral
label: BODY

text: review. The Fifth Circuit has recognized this dynamic by noting
label: BODY

text: that ‘[i]f all ineffective assistance of counsel claims were immune
label: BODY

text: from waiver, any complaint about process could be brought  in a
label: BODY

text: collateral attack by merely challenging the attorney’s failure to
label: BODY

text: achieve the desired result. A knowing and intelligent waiver should
label: BODY

text: not be so easily evaded.’ United States v. White, 307 F.3d 336, 344
label: BODY

text: Braxton at 503.
label: BODY

text: The Western District of Virginia further noted that the Tenth Circuit has also
label: BODY

text: distinguished collateral-attack waivers from the situation in Attar and that the Fourth Circuit’s
label: BODY

text: holding in United States v. Broughton-Jones, 71 F.3d 1143,1147 (4th Cir. 1995), also supports
label: BODY

text: such distinction. Braxton at 503, n. 2. Finally, the Braxton Court found it persuasive that the
label: BODY

text: majority of circuits to have confronted this question “have held that collateral attacks claiming
label: BODY

text: ineffective assistance of counsel that do not call into question the validity of the plea or the §
label: BODY

text: 2255 waiver itself, or do not related directly to the plea agreement or the waiver, are waivable.”
label: BODY

text: Id. at 503. (collecting cases).
label: BODY

text: In this case, petitioner asserts that he requested his counsel to appeal the errors made at
label: BODY

text: his sentencing, but that counsel failed to respond to his request. Therefore, petitioner asserts
label: BODY

text: counsel was per se ineffective for failing to file a notice of appeal as instructed. As held in
label: BODY

text: United States v. Poindexter, 2007 U.S. App. LEXIS 15360 (4th Cir. 2007) an evidentiary hearing
label: BODY

text: is required in such cases to determine whether the petitioner unequivocally instructed his
label: BODY

text: attorney to file a notice of appeal or, if his attorney was not so instructed, the court will
label: BODY

text: determine if petitioner met his burden of showing that: (1) his attorney had a duty to consult
label: BODY

text: under Roe v. Flores-Ortega, 528 U.S. 470 (2000); (2) his attorney failed to fulfill his consultation
label: BODY

text: obligations; and (3) he was prejudiced by his attorney’s failure to fulfill these obligations.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, I recommend this motion be denied on all grounds except the allegation of
label: BODY

text: failure to file notice of appeal hereinafter addressed.
label: BODY

text: Failure to File Notice of Appeal
label: HH1

text: Petitioner asserts that counsel was ineffective for failing to file an appeal of his amended
label: BODY

text: sentence. The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals has held that “a criminal defense attorney’s
label: BODY

text: failure to file a notice of appeal when requested by his client deprives the defendant of his Sixth
label: BODY

text: Amendment right to the assistance of counsel, notwithstanding that the lost appeal may not have
label: BODY

text: had a reasonable probability of success.” United States v. Peak, 992 F.2d 39, 42 (4th Cir. 1993).
label: BODY

text: In rendering this decision, the Court opined:
label: BODY

text: Persons convicted in federal district courts have a right to a direct
label: BODY

text: appeal. Coppedge v. United States, 369 U.S. 438, 82 S.Ct.917, 8
label: BODY

text: L.E.2d 21 (1962). In addition, the Sixth Amendment right to
label: BODY

text: counsel extends to the direct appeal, Douglas v. California, 372
label: BODY

text: U.S. 353, 83 S.Ct. 917, 8 L.Ed.2d 811 (1963), and it obligates the
label: BODY

text: attorney to file the appeal and identify possible issues for the court
label: BODY

text: even if, in the attorney’s opinion, those issues are not meritorious.
label: BODY

text: Anders v. California, 386 U.S.738, 87 S.Ct. 1396, 18 L.Ed.2d 493
label: BODY

text: Id. at 41.
label: BODY

text: Further, in Roe v. Flores-Ortega, 528 U.S. 470 (2000), the United States Supreme Court
label: BODY

text: recognized that “[i]f counsel has consulted with the defendant, the question of deficient
label: BODY

text: performance is easily answered: Counsel performs in a professionally unreasonable manner only
label: BODY

text: by failing to follow the defendant’s express instructions with respect to an appeal.” Flores-
label: BODY

text: Ortega, at 478.
label: BODY

text: In this case, petitioner asserts that he tried to appeal the errors made at his sentencing, but
label: BODY

text: that counsel failed to respond to his requests. Therefore, petitioner asserts counsel was per se
label: BODY

text: ineffective for failing to file a notice of appeal as instructed. The Government agrees that
label: BODY

text: counsel’s failure to file a notice of appeal when requested to do so is per se ineffective
label: BODY

text: assistance. The Government further states that based upon the affidavit of the petitioner alleging
label: BODY

text: that he requested that an appeal be filed, a genuine issue of material fact exists concerning the
label: BODY

text: effective assistance of counsel. The Government asserts that an evidentiary hearing is
label: BODY

text: appropriate on this issue.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, because the petitioner’s motion and the Government’s response establish
label: BODY

text: that there is a genuine issue of material fact, I find that an evidentiary hearing is necessary to
label: BODY

text: determine whether petitioner requested his attorney file an appeal and whether counsel ignored
label: BODY

text: or refused such instructions. See 28 U.S.C. § 2255 (providing in pertinent part that “[u]nless the
label: BODY

text: motion and the files and records of the case conclusively show that the prisoner is entitled to no
label: BODY

text: relief, the court shall cause notice thereof to be served upon the United States attorney, grant a
label: BODY

text: prompt hearing thereon, determine the issues and make findings of fact and conclusions of law
label: BODY

text: with respect thereto.”); see also United States v. Witherspoon, 231 F.3d 923 (4th Cir. 2000).
label: BODY

text: An evidentiary hearing, solely on the issue of whether petitioner instructed his counsel to
label: BODY

text: file an appeal shall be held at 10 am, September 6, 2007, in the United States Magistrate Judge
label: BODY

text: Courtroom, Room 433, 4th Floor, U.S. Courthouse, Wheeling, West Virginia.
label: BODY

text: Petitioner shall appear by telephone from his place of incarceration. Any other party,
label: BODY

text: counsel or witness who resides or whose principal office is more than 40 miles from the
label: BODY

text: Wheeling point of court may appear by telephone.
label: BODY

text: Brendan S. Leary, Esq. is appointed to represent petitioner at the evidentiary hearing.
label: BODY

text: IV.   RECOMMENDATION
label: HH1

text: Based upon a review of the record, the undersigned recommends that the petitioner’s
label: BODY

text: §2255 motion be denied and dismissed from the docket because petitioner knowingly,
label: BODY

text: intelligently, and voluntarily waived the right to collaterally attack the sentence with the
label: BODY

text: exception of an evidentiary hearing to determine whether petitioner requested his attorney to file
label: BODY

text: an appeal and whether counsel ignored or refused instructions.
label: BODY

text: Within ten (10) days after being served with a copy of this report and recommendation,
label: BODY

text: any party may file with the Clerk of Court written objections identifying those portions of the
label: BODY

text: recommendation to which objection is made and the basis for such objections. A copy of any
label: BODY

text: objections shall also be submitted to the Honorable Frederick P. Stamp, Jr., United States District
label: BODY

text: Judge. Failure to timely file objections to this recommendation will result in waiver of the right
label: BODY

text: to appeal from a judgment of this Court based upon such recommendation. 28 U.S.C. §
label: BODY

text: 636(b)(1); Thomas v. Arn, 474 U.S. 140 (1985); Wright v. Collins, 766 F.2d 841 (4th Cir. 1985):
label: BODY

text: United States v. Schronce, 727 F.2d 91 (4th Cir. 1984), cert. denied, 467 U.S. 1208 (1984).
label: BODY

text: The Clerk is directed to mail a copy of this Report and Recommendation to the pro se
label: BODY

text: plaintiff and counsel of record, as applicable.
